byline.contributor: Louise Story reported from New York, and Alejandra Xanic von Bertrab from Oaxaca, Mexico.
byline.original: By LOUISE STORY and ALEJANDRA XANIC von BERTRAB

abstract: Alejandro Murat Hinojosa, one of Mexico's top housing officials, and his family members have bought at least six homes in United States, and ownership has often been obscured on deeds or through shell companies; first homes were bought by Murat's father Jose Murat Casab, former Oaxaca governor, who tried to project Everyman image (Series: Towers of Secrecy).
lead_paragraph: The properties stand in contrast to the working-man image promoted by José Murat Casab, a longtime party insider, and his son, a top housing official.

headline.main: Mexican Political Family Has Close Ties to Ruling Party, and Homes in the U.S.
headline.print_headline: Political Clout in Mexico, Homes in the U.S.

snippet: The properties stand in contrast to the working-man image promoted by José Murat Casab, a longtime party insider, and his son, a top housing official.
